commentBody: Family event, will return tomorrow or Saturday, and look forward to rejoining!  Wishing each of you at least one big happy surprise‚Ä¶.

I learned yesterday that Jingle Bells isn't actually a Christmas song - it was written about winter travel and never references Christmas in the lyrics. My mind was blown and I've been talking about it to anyone that will listen all day. Imagine my surprise to see this theme.

I found this puzzle lots of fun, but I did not use the theme while solving. It was tough to get the last few words right in the lower left, my last to fall.

I confess I found the clue "Right-eous path?" for EAST not particularly well crafted: I don't view east as a "path" in any sense.
Personal best for a Thursday, what a nice Christmas present.

I haven't always agreed with it, but I thought you folks had a policy of avoiding words that are obscene or deeply offensive to distinct groups of people. So how could you possibly allow 13A?  The notion of a Caesar salad based on KALE is an absolute obscenity, and highly offensive to those who love good food.

Amoeba's favorite carol:

Single cells
Single cells
Single all the way
Oh what fun it is
To slide with a lone force on substrate 

(I had snow business posting that.)

To my fellow puzzlers: A merry Christmas to those who celebrate and a happy, peaceful holiday season. May your days and nights be blessed with beautiful vignettes, good food, edifying community, and the wonder that these quiet moments bring. Sending all my love and compassion your way, now and always. üíô
Thanks, Sam! Figuring out the theme helped me with typos! I hope everyone enjoys this one, as I did. Merry Christmas to all who celebrate. I wish y‚Äôall peace! üéÖüèªüéÑ

I was able to point my compasS NORTh, be a solver WHO OPtimizes my theme-guessing skills, and lollygaG RINgs around all the lollygaggers. To wit: I saw that it was going to be laughing all the way! Ha! Theme adjacent: here is a two-cat open sleigh, cutest thing ever: https://youtube.com/shorts/uySjw-ex__k?si=hNLeG0zwd7NWUFQc
Brah?  That‚Äôs a new one for me‚Ä¶. Pretty easy otherwise‚Ä¶

Easiest ezersky puzzle ever. 
I couldn‚Äôt believe the constructor name when I solved it. 
It‚Äôs a Christmas miracle.
Happy Holidays to everyone. Loved easy drop ins like BYTHEHORNS RICHARDHARRIS to go along with caroling references. In general enjoyed very much. Was a little hung up on time for a Thursday

Dear Deb,  A special note to thank you for your post on BlueSky today and especially for all your years of patiently helping us to be better solvers.  I started NYT Crosswords late in life after retirement and am so grateful for your support and humor.  Your columns are always so personal as well as helpful and you will be greatly missed. 

All best wishes for a fulfilling retirement and more time to spend with family. 

With deep gratitude.

A puzzle based on LAUGHING all the way, and a song that is associated with the 25th of December (or any time there's snow, actually).

So we have LOL, HEH, HAR HAR, TEHEE and HAHA.

Conspicuously absent is 

HO HO HO.

Sam, someone may be on the naughty list.

Fun little Christmas Eve puzzle before I go to bed. Not tough and that‚Äôs OK. I think there‚Äôll be fewer complaints given that it‚Äôs Christmas Eve.

Ho ho ho! And‚Ä¶. Mehhhhhhrry Christmas!
A jolly, holiday- and weather-appropriate theme from Sam that includes one of his Spelling Bee favorites. Fun.
Merry merry Christmas, friends. This place is a light in the darkness (even when we argue;)
Merry Christmas! Thanks for taking it easy on us. Busy day coming up.
So glad I found my crossword hobby this year, and this new quirky community. Merry Christmas to all.

Ho Ho Ho, who wouldn't go?
The theme actually helped after I caught on.
Is the FLIRTINI in one of the movies, because I only watched the show where they drank Cosmos?
Merry Christmas to all and to all a good night.
Undone by obscure trivia. Santa left me a lump of coal this Christmas. Ho ho ho.
This was as easy as the radii of pie slices -- good clue, that one -- but what the heck, it was a fun Christmas puzzle.

I was worried seeing Sam‚Äôs byline but this was a pleasant Christmas gift (from one Jew to another as it turns out). Maybe Wednesday-ish but worthy since it runs on Christmas, had TWO themes more or less so had an Ezersky level of construction complexity, and enough tricky clues to go along with the gimmes (RICHARDHARRIS for me, too bad he is more famous for Harry Potter over Camelot). A few random thoughts‚Äî RICHARDHARRIS was also the name of a very noteworthy oncologist at Cincinnati Children‚Äôs hospital, where I work; and coincidentally LARRYDOLAN who was also clued recently is the name of an excellent endocrinologist there. How weird is that? Can anyone hear the word LOLLYGAG and not think of this scene from ‚ÄúBull Durham‚Äù? https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=RjtmKIWa4tY One of these days I will stop mixing up Michael CERA and John Cena; today was not that day I tried to fit in HOSTDRESSER for SNL VIP. My friend Donna Richards has had that role for thirty years and it‚Äôs one of the most stressful jobs in the business. Agree with Steve L I missed HO HO as well That‚Äôs all I have‚ÄîMerry Christmas to all and to all a good night!

its not often that i find the mini more grin worthy than the maxi.
today was such a day...

Was waiting for the fun twist or devious trick, but it never came. That‚Äôs OK, I suppose. You can‚Äôt catch someone out if they‚Äôre always on their guard. Thanks for another year of great crosswording fun. This was the year that I finally broke the 1000 day streak after blowing it at 921 days a few years ago when I forgot until a couple of minutes before midnight‚Ä¶ onward to 1500 in 2026, I hope!

My holiday was sidelined by some Grinch at Costco who passed along something that I am still coughing up, 6 days later. So I am grateful to Sam for providing something that went down easy yet was still very satisfying, like a warm bowl of tomato soup. 

Happy spirit of the season to everyone here. May all who celebrate Christmas enjoy a great holiday feast. Just don‚Äôt serve Kale Caesar Salad. Nobody wants that.

Merry Christmas crosslandia!

Cute theme, but a bit easy for a Thursday, in 10 flat.

I hope everyone gets to spend some time with loved ones.

My wife is cooking for 2 days straight and we're in a food coma. My folks are over and so our post dinner activity consisted of 4 of us shoveling the foot of snow that came down today, in - 20C temps. It only took us 20 minutes (as opposed to 90 by myself). But it's wonderful to have a white Christmas.

Wishing you and yours a very happy holiday.

I have successfully (cleanly) solved the last couple of Sam E difficult puzzles. Huzzah!!

Alas, today I was stumped on 31A and 31D.

I knew neither ?IRK nor ?OR. They are nowhere in my bingo ball cage.

To me, that Dee cost me an EFF. My transcript is ruined! Ruined, I tell you!! 

HAR! It's all good! 

Happy holidays to all who celebrate! Sending an extra measure of love and light to those of who find the holidays difficult for whatever reason.üïØÔ∏è ü§óüïØÔ∏è

Merry Christmas and happy holidays to all in lovely Crosslandia! LAUGHING out loud at the theme today. We watched ‚ÄúA Christmas Story‚Äù as usual, but we added ‚ÄúA Christmas Story Christmas‚Äù this year as well. I loved it. They sing ‚ÄúJingle Bells‚Äù in the car‚Ä¶ in both movies ü§£ And yea, that song will be the ear worm for a while‚Ä¶ü§£ thanks Sam! üòù https://youtu.be/VAl-pDRsRAc?si=uBHEsE78mPGbQFO9 The Pineapple Express brought crazy weather to our neck of the woods (San Diego for Christmas). So middle child had second leg of his flight to join us moved to tomorrow morning. After he sat at the airport in Flagstaff for two hours, we cancelled his flights and he‚Äôs joining our oldest son instead. We will catch up to them on Friday. Bad flu bugs kept two other family members from joining us as well. All that to say wishing everyone out there safe travels and good health for this holiday season.

Why HO when you can HEH. That's what a socially awkward Santa would utter, no doubt.

So many expressions that I say but never spell. Well, more like EXHALE üòÆ‚Äçüí® especially on the 25th. Be merry, y'all!

I‚Äôm having a wonderful Christmas with my daughter and her family in Southern California.  It‚Äôs been great to be here when my youngest grandchild and only granddaughter has just started crawling. Tomorrow should be pretty special with her and her almost 5-year-old brother.  

I hope everyone out there is enjoying the holiday season with their loved ones.  Have a Merry Christmas and a great 2026, everyone.

Dashing! I enjoyed this one, and I had a relieved EXHALE when I finished because I was intimidated knowing it was Sam who constructed it. AND YET it didn‚Äôt have any devious elements; jolly all the way through. 

This is a busy week for someone in my line of work, but I‚Äôm happy to have had a sweet family time Wednesday night decking the halls with my husband and children, placing the presents under the tree, and watching ‚ÄúHow the Grinch Stole Christmas‚Äù (26 minutes is the right length of time for my kiddos). 

Being alive is so magical. I wish you EACH a lovely holiday time, a PERIOD of togetherness and tradition and coziness.
I had a more difficult time solving yesterday‚Äôs than today‚Äôs, interestingly.
Merry Christmas to my fellow crossworders! It‚Äôs  a rainy, windy Xmas here in the Bay Area,  and I am keeping fingers crossed that the power stays on.

41 degrees Celsius here for Xmas. 
Enjoyed this puzzle a lot for a Thursday!

Overall an easy Thursday (waiting for the rebus that never came!), but stuck for ages at the end with CARMOD instead of PERIOD! 

Time to learn how to spell REAGAN I suppose

Since the December 23 midnight deadline has passed and I had not heard the Christmas-song-that-shall-not-be-named, I won. But just now I was watching a short clip from t the first Christmas episode from West Wing that contains said Christmas-song-that-shall-not-be-named. Phew! https://youtu.be/MBoCOEwt77Q?si=roGcuIii1h1aG3A4
Wouldn‚Äôt mind some branched clues for things like brands, 39D could have had ‚Äúor Inaros‚Äô flagship‚Äù. Tenye wa Yuletim xush, loite ü§ì

I work in a retail pharmacy, so I'm subject to the overhead sound track my entire working day. I'm both happy and sad to say that I made it to December 17 this year before I heard this song, but at least it was the Spanish version!

Hearing that particular Christmas song makes me picture a Hallmark greeting card with a big-eyed Margaret Keane illustration of the kid in question, and it also makes me want to smash something against a brick wall.

What a pleasant surprise to find a Sam Ezersky puzzle that didn't live up to the terror that struck my heart when I saw the byline. And on a Thursday, no less. 

Just a breezy and quick solve, with more than a few chuckles along the way. In keeping with the holiday spirit, I'll leave out the ones that made my eyebrows arch.

Merry Christmas to those who are celebrating, and Happy Holidays to everyone else!

This was fun!
Thankful Santa did not bring the rebus that would have stolen Christmas! üòÖ
Have a Merry Christmas, all!

Ended with 2 letters I didn‚Äôt know. So I gave my phone to my pet monkey and voila. Lookout AI. 

Merry Christmas Y‚Äôall
HOstess HO HOs
Now there, Deb, La Guardia is a LOT nicer than it used to be.
As a Christmas gift to Sam and everybody else afflicted by the song-that-shall-not-be-named, I remind you all of the cure for an earworm: singing ‚ÄúThe Girl from Ipanema.‚Äù

I've watched way more Sex and the City than I care to admit, and yet somehow have never heard of the FLIRTINI. Now I have to add "re-watch all seasons of SATC" to my New Year's resolutions. Thanks a bunch, Sam. :) PS Interesting article on the nefarious history of Jingle Bells:https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/theatre-survey/article/story-i-must-tell-jingle-bells-in-the-minstrel-repertoire/D42C78950A58BDB88290954F73B195B2
This felt more like a Tuesday. But that‚Äôs a nice Christmas gift!
Merry Christmas my fellow cross word solvers..
Merry Christmas from the EAST(ern) edge of Pennsylvania!

All that laughter, and nary a HO HO HO.

Merry Christmas, y'all. Find yourself a bit of peace for today.

I'm not going to be the one to go all Scrooge on this puzzle.  No "Bah!  Humbug!" from me.
But it's Thursday!
It feels like it's been ages since we had a decent Thursday-style gimmick in a puzzle.

Yes, it's Christmas, and it's fitting to get a Christmas-themed puzzle, but can't it be a bit trickier?
[And isn't WHITE HEELS a bit on the "Geen-Paint-y" side?]

Agree with the vibe that this was the easiest Ezersky in memory. 

I was all set to come in kvetching about how [Chilliness] is not remotely a synonym for APLOMB. I read through the comments, mystified that nobody else had pointed this out. And then ‚Äî happily BEFORE I hit ‚Äúpost,‚Äù unlike what Deb relates in her column ‚Äî the penny dropped ‚Ä¶. 

Another good reminder than 99% of the time, it‚Äôs you making the mistake not the editing team :).  

Meanwhile about those Tuesday NFL games ‚Äî I thought at first it might be a Christmas-day thing but in fact it‚Äôs even rarer than that: at least according to Google (forgive the massive energy use for the AI lookup here) Tuesday games in recent decades have all been last-minute reschedulings because of COVID (in 2020 and 2021) or snowstorms (2010). 

Thanks to Will and the whole team for giving us this daily source of challenge and amusement!

Oh, the perils of too many crossing letters.  Seeing so many, I quickly filled in HEADWAITER without any doubts.  Especially since I had no idea about a cable lead-in to TV and staring at T_U, and we already had an IOTA, I mean, heck, what was there to think about?  Luckily, as I near my 86th birthday, I no longer obsess about solving completely correctly.  Merry Christmas, everyone!

That was a fun solve. 

Today‚Äôs mini is a fun construction too.
Sleazo???!!!!!!! Sometimes I am happy when the puzzle teaches me a new word (like Flirtini!) but sometimes I just become more convinced that a thing is not a word.

HA HAppy Christmas to those Puzzle People who celebrate.
This was a nice puzzle theme with which to  give a nod to the season without excluding anybody (except those of us without SNOW... here, we had a record high of 80 degrees. HOO BOY, indeed.)

Hmm, well, I disagree with the clue for 1D; one can be cool as a cucumber without exuding a chilly aura.  Humph.
And the Bee quite often spells 16A with an A in the first syllable, much to my annoyance...but just look at who is spelling it otherwise today!  

Also, phooey on PELLA...who did not stand behind a defective sliding door that allowed a main room to be flooded in a storm.  

Quite the span of eras, eh?  A  WWII novel, The REAGAN YEARs, even  THE EU.  
And remember when "1984" was distant and unimaginable?  No LAUGHING matter now....  but determined to hope.
Nice puzzle. But a Christmas Day puzzle with the theme of laughter and no "HO, HO, HO"?  Disappointing and a missed fun opportunity.

@Deb ‚Äî Re asking the puzzle editors for help, and then figuring it out on your own:  In my first job as a computer programmer, one of my colleagues said, ‚ÄúWhat we need around this joint is an intelligent-looking mannequin.‚Äù  Whenever we‚Äôd be stuck working on a program, we‚Äôd go to a colleague, explain the issue, and halfway through slap ourselves on the forehead and say, ‚ÄúOh, I see it.‚Äù  The colleague hadn‚Äôt really done anything besides sit there with an intelligent look on their face.

I'm an SATC diehard and it took me FOREVER to come up with FLIRTINI. I think the only mention of that cocktail comes in S2 E4, "They Shoot Single People, Don't They?" (featuring a very young Bradley Cooper!). Great pull.

Merry Christmas, all!

Good long workout for me, but ended up being an enjoyable Thursday solve. And... really wasn't catching on to the theme until I was almost done and went back and reviewed everything. That's just a nice touch. And.. appropriate puzzle find today: A Sunday from December 21, 2008 by Elizabeth C. Gorski with the title "Laughing all the way." A string of theme answers: 69a: LOOKWHOSHERE 74d: "December 25 answer to 69-Across?" JOLLYSTNICK A couple other theme answers: \ KRISKRINGLE SANTABABY And then... 10d (at the very middle at the top of the puzzle - "Greeting from 74 down." And that answer was 21 rebus squares - the rebus in each of them being "HO" So.... HOHOHOHOHOHOHOHOHOHOHOHOHOHOHOHOHOHOHOHOHO Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=12/21/2008&g=10&d=D ....
A gut Chineizish esn un a film to all who celebrate

Merry Christmas to all who celebrate. Ours was on the 21st (Yule) so we‚Äôre in a happy post celebration stupor today. A brisk walk in the freezing cold to the pub is as energetic as it‚Äôs going to get.

A very easy, breezy none Rebus Thursday; even more of a surprise given the constructor, but a pleasant one nonetheless. 

I note the lack of HO HO HO, but love the Jingle Bell theme. 

Have a happy, peaceful holiday with those you love. See you in the New Year.

LOL, but a puzzling puzzle. I don't understand the clue about cable lead-in for TV. Why is that "tru"?  Also, stumbled on the EU, but I see it now. The two of these together tripped me up at 49. Also sleazo vs. sleaze in the lower right corner.
How is this a Thursday? Bizarre

Finally, a Sam Ezersky puzzle that didn't leave me muttering under my breath. And as for "the game", do people voluntarily deprive themselves of watching the Bing Crosby-David Bowie duet? That's a cherished Christmas tradition for me!

SLEAZO? Okay, if you say so, Sam. I always thought SLEAZe was bad enough.

As for the rest of the puzzle, it was lovely, and fun, and so nice for a day when I don't want to work too hard, but still want a challenge. 

I spent the last two days baking, but our planned trip to see the kids tomorrow may not work out. Climatologist son-in-law is watching the storm for us; if it starts late enough in the day, we may make it there and back in enough time. However, son and d-i-l returned from a cruise with some unnamed illness, so we won't see them. I hope we're not stuck in the house with all these cookies! (Hm, neighbors may benefit...)

To those of you celebrating, get off your phones and laptops and go make memories. Take lots of photos.

To those, like us, whose holiday is over and are vegging today, it's a good time to go through file cabinets and shred! I've already watched two versions of Dickens Christmas Carol (whatever happened to Mr. Magoo? That was my favorite version). 

Dinner at friends' tonight. They firmly said "do not bring anything" so I will crochet a toy for their cat. So there. (Mom said never show up empty handed. Mom comes first.)

Enjoy it all! See you tomorrow!

Hmmm... some quite unusual puzzle finds. Four puzzles - 
A Wednesday from August 28, 1985 by Eugene T. Maleska. Three 15 letter theme answers in that one - top to bottom: 

TOLOVEONESELFIS
THEBEGINNINGOFA
LIFELONGROMANCE

And then...  A Tuesday from May 26, 1992 by Alfio Micci. The theme answers in that one - exactly the same, top to bottom. 

And.. a Thursday from July 7, 1994 by Ed Early. Again - the same theme answers top  to bottom. 

And.. a Tuesday from July 7, 1998 by Elizabeth C. Gorski. Once again - exactly the same. Hmmm... 

Never come across that before. 

....
Was totally t-boned by TBONES üò°

Helen from Somerset said it better than I could, so I'll quote, "A very easy, breezy none Rebus Thursday." Particularly enjoyable fills were the British actor, one of my favorites, and APLOMB, one of my favorite words.

However, my very favorite thing today was Deb's column. (Sam, don't be offended--I'll get to your Bee later.) Deb, you are peaking now??

Sloppy.

Too many unknown word usages (or quite possibly made up to fit the puzzle). UTAHN? I have heard of Utahans‚Ä¶ SLEAZO? I have heard Sleaze or sleaze ball used‚Ä¶ maybe it‚Äôs a regional thing?

I don‚Äôt get GEEKS for Uber enthusiasts or POL for one who runs‚Ä¶

üßª üí©

31:49, 22:13 faster than my Thu average. Went and solved a few Wed puzzles from Jan 2000 and they all took closer to an hour. One thing I noticed was there a lot more naticks that took a lot of guessing. I think there‚Äôs been a more deliberate editorial effort in recent times to reduce naticks (complaints to the contrary notwithstanding). This is of course based on a sample of 3 from the archives (add your own dose of salt here). 

I was expecting to see a HOHOHO emerge in the theme but that would have been too perfect.

An easy Thursday leaves those of you who celebrate with more time to spend with your families... and me plenty of time to continue my quest to brush up on my pre-2010 pop culture knowledge.  Gotta get my crossword times down somehow.  Today was 13:05, but it would've been at least a minute faster if I'd known MOES, LESH, FLIRTINI or RICHARDHARRIS.

(And crossword times aside, catching up on old movies has been fun.  I quite enjoyed Back to the Future, so thank you to the commenter who was shocked I'd never seen it and suggested I rectify that.)

Happy Thursday (or Merry Christmas!) to all :)
In what dictionary did you find "chilliness" for "aplomb"?  No bueno . . .

In my case for today, 1A should have been CUTECUTECUTE. For the extra credit, I think this is one theme with bonus content. Or supporting content, really, not so much bonus. 

Merry Christmas to everyone celebrating. To accommodate the many healthcare workers in my family, we do presents around the tree on the 26th, which means today is some last-minute wrapping, a good and festive dinner out, and lots of enjoyment of all the many incredible gifts we have already been given throughout this year. Wishing all of my fellow puzzlers a similarly contented and grateful day.
Enjoyed the laughter, thanks for a nice Christmas puzzle

Sure raining hard here‚Ä¶ I‚Äôm not much of a deadhead, but Phil Lesh‚Äô Box of Rain is sublime (with Robert Hunter of course). It‚Äôs all a dream we dreamed long ago. https://youtu.be/Bxh5olGxCYI?si=XSCWek1pQSqmXw1Y
I was having a great Christmas until I saw Sam Ezersky's name on the crossword

EMO didn't occur to me, the way my mind works now, but a discussion shortly before this taught me a brand-new word "SLEAZO"! Before that Deb had kindly provided the L of LGA and when I looked up the brand-new word PELLA, sure enough, windows and doors! I have HEADW_ITER at 28D. R seems likely but I tried A as well when that didn't work. Neither makes sense in the T_U I have across it. There has to be something else wrong somewhere. Aha! It was something that happens to me over and over: Where I had typed MOES it had changed to MOEH, and my GEEKS/TUE had become GEKKS/TUK. What could cause that?

RICHARD HARRIS was Dumbledore in the first Harry Potter??? How did I not notice that? It must have been the beard that threw me off. I think of his roles in "Guns of Navarone," "The Wild Geese," or the IRA bag man in "Patriot Games." And yes, English Bob. Never saw "A Man Called Horse." So Harry Potter would not have been my first choice for the clue. Not a hater at all, in fact I got my niece a plush Hedwig, and apparently I won Christmas with that gift.

I'm waiting to hear how my nephew enjoyed his first Feast of Seven Fishes - he's marrying into an Italian family. (I would starve at such a feast.)

A quick puzzle, between work and dashing to Christmas dinner at my Sister-in-Law's, across the border, on the north shore of Cat Lake.  Merry Christmas to Deb, Sam C., Caitlin; Sam E.; and all my fellow Wordplayers! Joy be yours this holiday season!
Can someone please explain IOTA as the answer to 40 Across? Thanks

The second i saw "Sam Ezersky" I thought we were in for a Scrooge'd puzzle. But, mirabile dictu, 'twas a veritably joyous and entirely palatable verbal feast. Ezersky was transformed...God bless us, everyone!

Not sure if I landed on Sam Ezersky‚Äôs naughty or nice list üòóüéÖüéÑwith this puzzle. No LOLLYGAGing with this one ‚Ä¶ no SIREE. üéâ
To my dear crossword puzzle friends & outstanding NYT staff ‚Ä¶ Happy HolidaysüéÑto you & yours.
I was sure that "Raider in times past" was going to be HAN (as in Solo, Harrison Ford's previous role before playing a certain Raider of the lost ark). Overthinking it!

Oohhh - one more puzzle find. A Tuesday from October 6, 2009 by Matt Ginsberg. First theme clue and answer: "Only common word in the English language with the consecutive letters MPG" CAMPGROUND And the clues for the rest of theme just had the consecutive letters in the clue: ...ADQ... HEADQUARTERS ...KSG... THANKSGIVING ...ZKR... BLITZKRIEG ...SPB... RASPBERRY ...NKC...CRANKCASE Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=10/6/2009&g=62&d=A ....
Didn't quite get it, but thought it was a genuinely fun theme. Merry Christmas to my fellow-puzzlers!
Merry Christmas, Deb!

This is my first post to this forum and I write it to say, to the people who I know would truly appreciate this: Today is DAY 1000 of my streak!!! I didn‚Äôt plan for it to happen on Christmas Day, it‚Äôs just wonderfully serendipitous that it did :)

How nice to see all the cheerful holiday messages. Posting this late, after Christmas dinner of the traditional turkey.

Help again please: PR - RICO?
I think of 'dude' as slang, is it standard American now?

Very doable. 

Seasons Greetings from across the way.
I will miss you, Deb.
Seems to me only a real SLEAZO would actually use that word. üòõ

The best puzzles are the ones that teach us something.  Knowledge can come from anywhere if we're paying attention, so never hesitate when you're hopelessly stuck to go looking for an answer elsewhere.  After a puzzle is done and forgotten, the knowledge we gained is still with us .

Gyros are Greek. Shawarma is Arabic. Greeks eat a lot of pork and don‚Äôt do halal. So no, there would never be a gyro on a halal cart. As my Greek family puts it, everyone loves Greek food and changes their food to sound Greek. 

My area has a huge Palestinian population. They are all opening restaurants and calling them Mediterranean food. To the non-Greeks: ‚ÄúOoh Mediterranean, Greece is in the Mediterranean. I love that food‚Äù. It‚Äôs not the same. Just like a gyro is not halal. 

It‚Äôs pronounced ‚Äúyeer-row‚Äù for anyone in that debate.

Kind of a tough Thursday to me, with a fun harmless theme.

Good cluing overall, I had a ton of trouble in the northeast area.  I had trouble thinking of SURF cause I was thinking there was some obscure word for the white foam on the beach.  And crossing FLIRTINI which I've never heard of and SUPERSTATE from a book I haven't read since I was 17.

Deb I didn‚Äôt do last Thursday in time to comment but so wanted to thank you for building this community and helping us all over our humps with the crossword.
Love, Merry Christmas and wishing you a wonderful retirement ahead!!!

Lots of fun words and some new ones for me today. Wonderful timing as I watched RICHARDHARRIS as Dumbledore after my dinner (promptly followed by a nap!). That first, and maybe even best, Harry Potter movie is wonderfully Christmassy without ever really being a Christmas Movie. 

Deb, thank you again for your columns, I‚Äôve not been here too long but in my short stay you have been a most courteous host - and to everyone else, whatever or wherever you‚Äôre celebrating (or even if you‚Äôre not), I hope you all have/had a lovely day. 

Merry Christmas!

One more quite amazing puzzle find. A Sunday from April 1(!) 2018 by Sam Exersky with the title "1 + 1 = 5" Some theme answers, all straightforwardly clued: KIDINAC&YSTORE P&AEXPRESS L&OCALRISSIAN ALLH&SONDECK YANKEEDOODLED&Y AFISHCALLEDW&A And there were more. Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=4/1/2018&g=68&d=A It's late, so I'll probably re-post this tomorrow. ...
Lovely! Laughing all the way ‚ù§Ô∏è

Not to be a grinch, but man I did not like this one. Then again, Ezersky and I never do get along. Felt the fill was sloppy, with UTAHN, ENSURES for "sews up", NUN, and what's the deal with the clue for SNL VIP not having an abbreviation in the answer?

On another note, thanks for all your columns Deb, you will be missed!!!

sam sam sam.... coal for you, you SLEAZO!
har har har, trick or treat.

Thank you Sam, for a fun and gentle Thursday puzzle. 

Thank you XWord Community for making this a warm and welcoming place. 

May peace be with you all. ‚ù§Ô∏èüíö
The most agreeable puzzle from Sam Ezersky that I‚Äôve had the pleasure of attempting. Happy Boxing Day to all who celebrate. Cheers!

Also offline for a few days. Enjoy the peace and quiet.

@Marc Leroy Anderson's "Sleigh Ride" was written as an instrumental; the lyrics were commissioned 3 years later and written by Mitchell Parish. It too is a winter song which now rarely gets heard once Christmas is in the rearview mirror. fwiw it's a fun song both to sing and to play; percussion and trumpet get special treats in the whipcrack and the horse's neigh at the end. I can't find a good live version with full orchestra and chorus, so here's an instrumental only. At least they knew where to point the camera for the horse's neigh. ;) https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DZ98oN9LN98

@Steve L I've heard the "Jingle Bells was originally a Thanksgiving song", though Snopes says there's no evidence of thanksgiving per se, just generic winter. (https://www.snopes.com/fact-check/christmas-song-jingle-bells-history/)

@Emu fodder

Hmmm...and I actually prefer gloomy and depressing movies.  I wonder why that is?

I remember a long time ago, when I was in high school, seeing the movie "Finnegan's Rainbow".  It had Petula Clark in it, which made it something I had to see.  It dealt with topics of things like racism.

And it should have been beautiful to me as a young, idealistic kid.  Everything turned out like an explosion of happy Irish music in a blue-skyed Irish Spring.

But I suddenly realized I didn't buy it anymore.  I was too jaded to think that life really followed a happy arc, with a nice solution at the end.  I suddenly realized that all that happiness was fake.  

And so the movie depressed me enormously, precisely because it was so upbeat.

I've been upside down ever since.

Back in the 60‚Äôs I worked at Sears. The Christmas music was on a 90 minute loop. They used the same loop for the three seasons I worked there. 

It was really weird because all of the employees subconsciously learned the sequence. We‚Äôd mutter the name of the next up song in unison. Customers were amazed.

@Gigi Gyros may be traditionally Greek, but there are plenty of halal restaurants (including food trucks) that do halal gyros (see e.g. https://halalgyroexpresskebab.com/). Even Greek gyros aren't always pork, so gyros aren't inherently haram, and while it is probably partly "lets make this sound Greek" influence, that doesn't change the fact that halal gyros exist.

@Gigi  There is a restaurant near me called Halal Bitez that specializes in gyros and kabobs (lamb, chicken, beef). I think ‚Äúhalal‚Äù refers to the preparation, not the origin of the dish. Maybe gyros are also commonly served at halal carts. Regardless, they are delicious!!
